abstract.para: This guide contains an overview of &productname; on the &rpi; platform and will guide you through the setup procedure.

sect1.title: Platform Overview
sect1.para: To be able to use &productname;, a &arm64; compatible &rpi; is required. &productname; is tested to work on a &rpi; 3 Model B board.

sect2.title: The &rpi; 3 Model B
sect2.para: The &rpi; is a series of small single-board computers based on a System on a Chip (SoC) by Broadcom*, featuring various peripherals on the board.

variablelist.title: Selected Features of the &rpi; 3 Model B

listitem.para: The Broadcom SoC includes a quad-core ARM* Cortex*-A53 cores supporting the ARMv8 32-bit and 64-bit instruction sets. With the default configuration, it is clocked at 1.2 GHz.
1024 MiB DDR2 memory mounted on the back of the board.
Broadcom* VideoCore* IV providing OpenGL ES 2.0 support. Displays can be connected over HDMI or composite (TRRS jack).
A USB Ethernet adapter on the board provides 10/100MBit/s Ethernet.

The BCM43438 chip supports IEEE-802.11g, IEEE-802.11b and IEEE-802.11n in the 2,4 GHz band. It also provides Bluetooth 2.0-4.1 (Low Energy). Note that Bluetooth is not supported by the kernel in &productname;.
The &rpi;'s main power source is the Micro USB connector. It is recommended to use the bundled power supply only.
A total of four USB 2.0 ports is available.
A 0.1 inch multi-function pin header is also available. Note that not all functionality of this header is exposed in SLES.

sect2.title: &productname; &productnumber;
sect2.para: &productname; &productnumber; is the first enterprise-class operating system available free-of-charge for the &rpi;. During its lifetime, &productname; &productnumber; systems on &rpi; will receive all released feature and maintenance updates after registration.

listitem.para: The Toolchain Module contains the toolchain (GCC, ...) for an enhanced software development experience combined with the SDK. It is updated yearly to provide more up
The Web and Scripting Module contains a newer version of the PHP and Python scripting languages.
The Containers Module contains several packages revolving around containers and related tools, including Docker

sect2.para: For more information about modules and extensions, see SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 Modules.

sect1.title: Installation
sect1.para: &productname; for &rpi; is distributed as XZ-compressed image file for MicroSD cards. This section will guide you through the process of preparing the card to the first boot. If you already have a MicroSD card containing the image, you can skip straight to .

note.title: SD Card Space Requirements
note.para: While the image itself only requires 2 GB of space, it is recommended to use a card with a capacity of at least 8 GB.

warning.title: All Data on the Card will be Lost!
warning.para: By following this procedure, all data on the SD card will be overwritten and therefore irrevocably lost!

sect2.title: Preparing the Card on Linux
sect2.para: Before and after you plug in the SD card, run lsblk. Between the two runs of lsblk, there should be a difference of one or more lines. The first column and first row is the name of the node representing the SD card in your system. To write the image to the card, use the dd command:

example.title: Writing the Image to the Card using dd
example.para: This command decompresses the image SLES-12-SP2-ARM-JeOS-raspberrypi3_aarch64.-Build2.62.raw.xz to the SD card mmcblk0.

sect2.title: Booting for the First Time
sect2.para: After insertion of the prepared MicroSD card, connect a display and a USB keyboard first, then provide power over Micro USB. After a few seconds you should be able to see a few lines of text on the screen. If that is not the case, recheck the connection to the display.
On the first boot, the system will expand to fill the entire SD card, so be patient.

note.title: Be patient!
note.para: The first boot may take up to half an hour with no visible changes to the display output. Is it important that you do not interrupt this process, otherwise you may end up with a unbootable system.

sect2.para: Once the system finished booting, you will see the following output on the screen:
Log into the system by entering root as username and linux as password. After a successful login, the shell prompt appears:
You are now logged into the system as root and can configure the system.

sect1.title: Initial system configuration
sect1.para: In this section is is explained how to perform the initial system configuration for &productname; on &rpi;.

sect2.title: Changing the &rootuser; Password
sect2.para: The image on the SD cards all share the same user and password combination, so it is recommended to assign a new password for the &rootuser; user. To do that, run the passwd command:
sect2.screen: &prompt.root; passwd New password: Retype new password: passwd: password updated successfully &prompt.root;

note.title: Invisible Password Input
note.para: When entering the password, you will not see the typed characters on screen. In fact, you may not notice at all that you are typing. That is an intentional effect for increased security.

sect2.title: Changing the Hostname
sect2.para: By default, no hostname is configured on the device. Follow these steps to change it.

step.para: Open the &yast; network module either by running yast2 lan or clicking the network icon in the &yast; control center.
Select Hostname/DNS in the top tab bar.
Type the new hostname into the Hostname field.
Click on OK to save the change. After &yast; exited, you need to log out and in again.

sect2.title: Setting up Networking
sect2.para: The default configuration has DHCP enabled on the ethernet port. If that suits your network environment, you can skip this section. If your require use of a static IP address, use &yast;:

step.para: Open the &yast; network module either by running yast2 lan or clicking the network icon in the &yast; control center.
In &yast;, you will see the network interface being selected. Choose Edit to open the address configuration.
Select Statically Assigned IP Address and type in the desired values for IP Address and Subnet Mask. Click Next.

With a static network configuration, you will also need to specify a DNS server (if applicable) and a gateway. For the gateway, select Routing in the tab bar and enter the IPs of the gateways into the specific fields.
The DNS server is set in the Hostname/DNS tab. After choosing that tab, enter the IPs of the nameservers into the respective Name Server fields.

sect2.para: For information about the network configuration in &productname;, see &admin;, Chapter 13 Remote Installation, Section 13.2.2 Setting Up an NFS Repository Manually (&docaddress;).
